reasoning: The critique targets the essay’s headline update (“~1% to ~5–10% Flourishing” and ‘rules out Flourishing close to 0’) by arguing the key evaluative quantities are underspecified and liable to shift across the essay’s many axiological/metaethical frameworks. That’s moderately central because it undermines how to interpret and justify the reported single scalar optimism update, but it doesn’t directly refute the essay’s substantive object-level arguments about convergence, trade, and threats (those could stand while the scalar is redefined/removed). The objection has moderate strength: it plausibly shows equivocation/instability in the ‘yardstick’ and so significantly weakens confidence in the numeric/probabilistic summary, but it doesn’t demonstrate the underlying qualitative conclusion (some optimism vs ~0) is false, and the position could be patched by explicitly fixing metrics or reporting a vector/range. Most claims are correct: the excerpt does not clearly define ‘mostly-great’ or the denominator of ‘% of what it might be,’ and different sections explicitly condition on different value-theoretic assumptions. Some language (e.g., ‘easy to make true’) is a bit speculative, so not perfect correctness. The critique is clear, focused on one issue, and contains little dead weight.
title: The optimism update equivocates because “flourishing” and its denominator are undefined and shifting
